Let‚Äôs build a brighter financial future for everyone, together!

I‚Äôm sharing this because student loan debt hits close to home for me.

I've been there, feeling the weight of loans on my shoulders.

But, I‚Äôm committed to continuing to fight to cancel student loan debt and make education more accessible for everyone.

Included is automatic enrollment, which kicks in if you‚Äôre 75 days late on a payment.

But first, the Department of Education needs access to your financial information.

I know that sounds intense, but if you‚Äôve ever filled out FAFSA, you're eligible for automatic enrollment!

Fast forward to July 2024, and the SAVE Plan makes your undergrad loans payments drop from 10% to 5% of your income.

AND, if you've borrowed $12,000 or less, your debt will be wiped clean after a decade of payments ‚Äì not 20-25 years.

The SAVE Plan rollout is happening in two phases.

The first happened this summer, with an expanded version of the program (that will slash monthly payments by HALF) launching next July.

And what if you‚Äôre already on an IDR plan?

You‚Äôll need to log in to StudentAid.gov to see if you are on the REPAYE Plan, and if not, you can submit a request through your federal student aid account.

There are a few ways to get started with SAVE. First, you can fill out the IDR application for the SAVE Plan, linked here: studentaid.gov/idr/

üö®While filling it out, make sure to select the option for your loan servicer to place you on the lowest monthly payment plan.üö®

The best part? You may already be enrolled!

The SAVE Plan replaced the Revised Pay As You Earn (REPAYE) Plan, so borrowers on the REPAYE Plan will be automatically enrolled!

‚Ä¶and if you weren‚Äôt already enrolled in the REPAYE Plan, signing up for SAVE is easy!

Check out this chart that breaks down monthly payments based on income and family size.

You'd only pay after earning over $40,000 annually. Incredible - right?

The SAVE Plan is an income-driven repayment plan, meaning your monthly payment is based on income and family size.

Imagine owing $0 a month! Under SAVE, federal student debt holders could be paying exactly that.

While we‚Äôre fighting for a more fair & equitable education system‚Äîthere‚Äôs another federal program that can help you pay off your student loans. It‚Äôs the most affordable repayment plan in U.S. history.

It‚Äôs called the Saving on Valuable Education (SAVE) Plan, here's how it works:

In August 2022, the Biden Administration issued an Executive Order to support student loan debt relief. This program aimed to cancel up to $20,000 in loans for eligible borrowers.

However, this June, the Supreme Court struck the Executive Order down.

Two months ago SCOTUS struck down Biden‚Äôs student loan forgiveness plan. So, where do we go from here?

In this thread I'll give you a rundown of what has happened so far and how an existing program can help you in your journey.

While the Radiation Exposure Compensation Act is meant to give compensation to those who have been affected by nuclear fallout, the law doesn‚Äôt extend to New Mexicans affected by the Trinity test site.

In the aftermath of the Trinity nuclear test, it‚Äôs tough to assess the full impact of nuclear fallout, but it‚Äôs estimated that 1,000 New Mexicans developed cancer as a direct consequence, and the infant mortality rate increased in the area as well.

Scientists KNEW radioactive fallout would be dangerous to those communities, but the government didn‚Äôt inform them, didn‚Äôt provide the opportunity to evacuate, and more than 78 years later, still has not compensated these communities.
Communities downwind in the Tularosa Basin were exposed to dangerous radiation levels. Mainly rural and agricultural communities, and the nuclear fallout landed on crops, animals, and water supplies.

On July 16, 1945, at 5:30 am, the U.S. Government detonated the first nuclear bomb at the Trinity test site in southern New Mexico. People nearly 200 miles away felt the blast across the communities of our District in NM-01 and far beyond.

It‚Äôs Oppenheimer release weekend. And part of this story takes place in my home state of New Mexico.

It‚Äôs a critical history to our national and global security. But it‚Äôs also important to be real about the impacts of this nuclear legacy in New Mexico. (Thread)

We have a moral & legal responsibility to Tribes to provide life sustaining waters promised by the trust & treaty responsibilities of the U.S. In Congress, I will never stop fighting to protect the rights of Indigenous nations &  their rights to water as I have my entire career.

The treaty of 1868 promised the Navajo Nation a ‚Äúpermanent home.‚Äù A home without water is a promise broken. And when Justices Kavanaugh, Roberts, Thomas, Alito, & Barrett turn on their tap tonight, I hope they think of the 170,000 Navajo citizens who live that broken promise.
The federal government has a legal and moral duty to protect the rights and provide water to Tribal Nations, and this decision is a shameful turning back of the clock on that promise.

Today the Court‚Äôs extremist majority ruled that the U.S. does not have an explicit trust responsibility to secure water for Tribal nations unless spelled out in treaty, undercutting the very foundation of the Winters Doctrine laid out in 1908 & litigated over the last 115 years.

The 1908 Winters decision by the Supreme Court established that tribal lands that were reserved by treaty or other federal actions also carried water rights to provide a sustainable homeland. Since then, the Winters decision has been the standard for tribal water rights.
Here‚Äôs the deal: Nearly 40% of Navajo families do not have access to water in their homes, and in some parts of the Navajo Nation, 91% of Navajo households lack access to water.

Let me be clear: This doesn‚Äôt just impact the Navajo Nation; it could impact water rights and access across Indian Country. It is a direct affront to Tribal rights, the federal trust responsibility, and 115 years of settled law under the Winters Doctrine.

This SHAMEFUL decision upends more than a hundred years of legal precedent at the expense of Tribal water rights and the Trust Responsibility.
